item.title: US Judge to Weigh Limiting Military Troops in LA on Thursday
item.description: California’s bid to limit military involvement in the Los Angeles immigration protests will be taken up by a judge Thursday, meaning that a pullback by the Trump administration before then is unlikely.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: National Guard soldiers outside the Edward R. Roybal Federal Building in Los Angeles, California, US, on Sunday, June 8, 2025. The deployment of National Guard troops by President Donald Trump over the weekend, despite the objections of state and city officials, led to growing friction between local leaders and the administration.

item.title: US Seeks to Halt Abrego Garcia Deportation Case After His Return
item.description: Days after Kilmar Abrego Garcia was brought back to the US to face human smuggling charges, the Trump administration asked a federal court to halt a lawsuit seeking answers over why the US hadn’t facilitated his return following his wrongful deportation to El Salvador.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: A picture of Kilmar Abrego Garcia during a news conference at Cannon House Office Building in Washington, DC, on April 9. Photographer: Alex Wong/Getty Images

item.title: Argentina’s Top Court Bans Kirchner From Office for Life
item.description: Argentina’s Supreme Court upheld former President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner’s fraud conviction, ratifying her sentence to six years in prison as well as a lifelong ban on holding public office, according to the court ruling reviewed by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Former Argentine President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner

item.title: How NYC’s Ranked-Choice Voting System Looms Over Mayoral Race
item.description: New York City’s mayoral contest has had plenty of drama ahead of the June 24 vote. The incumbent mayor, Eric Adams, decided not to participate in the Democratic primary in the wake of a corruption scandal and is running instead as an independent. The front-runner, former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, is attempting a political comeback after leaving office in 2021 following multiple allegations of sexual harassment. And Cuomo’s closest challenger for the Democratic nomination is Zohran Mamdani,
item.dc:creator: Stacie Sherman, Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: New York City mayoral candidates Adrienne Adams, from left, Brad Lander, Jessica Ramos, Zellnor Myrie, Andrew Cuomo, Whitney Tilson, Zohran Mamdani, Michael Blake, and Scott Stringer during a mayoral Democratic primary debate in New York, on June 4. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/AP Photo/Bloomberg

item.title: Reeves Defends UK Economic Choices as She Touts Public Spending
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will defend her fiscal choices and trumpet billions of pounds of infrastructure investment in the UK spending review on Wednesday, as Keir Starmer’s government seeks to regain momentum after a faltering first year in power.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves

item.title: Hydrogen Tax Credit Rescue ‘On the Table,’ GOP Senator Says
item.description: The Senate is considering a plan to save a lucrative tax credit for the production of hydrogen that would be scrapped in the tax-and-spending mega bill passed by the House, key Republicans said.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: A liquid green hydrogen plant in Woodbine, Georgia.

item.title: Mexico’s President Pushes Back on Claim She Encouraged LA Violence
item.description: US Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem accused Claudia Sheinbaum of encouraging anti-deportation protests in Los Angeles, drawing a rare rebuke from the Mexican leader who has sought to maintain cordial relations with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum

item.title: Education Secretary Says Harvard May See Grants Restored
item.description: Education Secretary Linda McMahon said that Harvard and other universities could get some of the federal funding cut by the Trump administration restored if they change their policies.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: US education secretary Linda McMahon

item.title: Marines Arrive in LA as Tensions Grow Over Immigration Raids
item.description: Marines deployed by President Donald Trump arrived in the Los Angeles area with orders to protect federal property and officers, as the city is gripped by tensions over anti-deportation protests.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, Alicia Clanton, John Gittelsohn

media:content.media:description: A convoy of buses moves along Interstate Highway 10 after leaving the Marine Corps base in Twentynine Palms, California, on June 9. Photographer: Gregory Bull/AP Photo

item.title: Amazon Security Chief Urges Hands-Off Approach to AI Regulation
item.description: Amazon.com Inc.’s chief security officer joined officials at other major tech companies in calling for fewer regulations in artificial intelligence, warning that government involvement in this rapidly emerging area risks narrowing the scope of the company’s work.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: An Amazon Web Services data center in Stone Ridge, Virginia, US, on Sunday, July 28, 2024. Data center developers in Northern Virginia are asking utility Dominion Energy Inc. for as much power as several nuclear reactors can generate, in the latest sign of how artificial intelligence is helping drive up electricity demand.

item.title: Senate Plans to Deliver Trump-Backed Tip, Overtime Tax Breaks
item.description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune said Republicans in his chamber expect to deliver on President Donald Trump’s campaign promises to exempt tips, overtime pay, Social Security and auto loan interest from taxes.
item.dc:creator: Cam Kettles, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: A server takes an order at a restaurant in the Ferry Building in San Francisco, California, US, on Thursday, March 27, 2025. The Bureau of Economic Analysis is scheduled to release personal consumption figures on March 28. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Bessent Returns to Washington as US-China Talks Stretch On
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent departed trade talks with China late Tuesday in London, as delegations continued to negotiate over key tech and industrial exports and deescalating their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Annmarie Hordern

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick on June 10.

item.title: Former Mayor Bloomberg Backs Cuomo in NYC Democratic Primary
item.description: Former New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg endorsed Andrew Cuomo in the city’s crowded Democratic mayoral primary, giving the former governor a boost two weeks before the election.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Andrew Cuomo, New York City mayoral candidate, speaks during the United Federation of Teachers (UFT) mayoral forum in New York, US, on Saturday, May 17, 2025. The New York mayoral primary elections are scheduled to be held on June 24.

item.title: The Political Fault Lines on Display in LA Unrest Response
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, economics editor Chris Anstey writes about research into how economics and crime drove voting patterns. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: US, Mexico Near Deal to Cut Steel Duties and Cap Imports
item.description: The US and Mexico are closing in on a deal that would remove President Donald Trump’s 50% tariffs on steel imports up to a certain volume, according to people familiar with the matter, a revamp of a similar deal between the trade partners during his first term.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux, Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: A worker cuts a stainless steel sheet at a steel manufacturing facility in Mexico City. Photographer: Mauricio Palos/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Poised to Repeal Biden Curb on Power-Plant Pollution
item.description: The Trump administration will propose scrapping Biden-era climate mandates requiring the nation’s power plants to curb planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions as soon as Wednesday, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Steam rises from a power plant in Adamsville, Alabama.

item.title: Macron Seeks Greenland Visit to Counter ‘Predation’ After Trump
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron said he plans to visit Greenland on Sunday to help counter any “predation” after US President Donald Trump said he wants to take over the self-ruling territory of Denmark.
item.dc:creator: Nayla Razzouk

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, France's president.

item.title: Trump Team Weighs Withholding Education Funding to California
item.description: US Education Secretary Linda McMahon said Tuesday the Trump administration was considering withholding education funding to California schools, alleging the state’s policies on transgender athletes violates federal law.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Stephanie Lai, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: The San Francisco skyline from Alcatraz Island in San Francisco, California, US, on Monday, May 5, 2025. President Donald Trump said in a Truth Social post on Sunday that he has ordered the reopening of Alcatraz as a prison to "house America's most ruthless and violent Offenders." Photographer: Ethan Swope/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says FEMA Phaseout to Begin After Hurricane Season
item.description: President Donald Trump said his team will move forward with winding down much of the Federal Emergency Management Agency — but not until after a hurricane season that some projections show could be particularly deadly.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse, Lauren Rosenthal, Brian K Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Technicians monitor Hurricane Ian inside the National Response Coordination Center at the FEMA headquarters in Washington, DC, on Sept. 28, 2022. Photographer: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images

item.title: Gabbard Warns Global Nuclear Annihilation Is Closer Than Ever
item.description: Tulsi Gabbard, the US director of national intelligence, released a video Tuesday warning that the world is closer to nuclear war than ever and accusing unnamed political elites of trying to foment conflict between world powers.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard

item.title: South Africa Names Rugby Captain, Business Leaders to National Dialogue Panel
item.description: South Africa’s president set up a panel that includes business leaders, actors and the captain of its national rugby team to guide a dialogue on the country’s future development path.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

media:content.media:description: Siya Kolisi

item.title: Chile’s Matthei Details Plan to Save Billions in Public Spending
item.description: Chile presidential candidate Evelyn Matthei laid out plans to save state coffers $1.5 billion annually by combating fraud and revamping government purchases, following a scandal over irregular medical leave by public employees.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Presidential candidate Evelyn Matthei

item.title: Bessent Emerging as a Contender to Succeed Fed’s Powell
item.description: A growing chorus of advisers inside and outside the Trump administration are pushing another name to serve as the next chair of the Federal Reserve: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.
item.dc:creator: Saleha Mohsin, Nancy Cook, Joshua Green

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary

item.title: Pakistan Raises Defense Budget 17% in Boost for Chinese Weapons Suppliers
item.description: Pakistan plans to raise its defense budget by 17% following its conflict last month with India, a boost expected to help Chinese weapons suppliers.
item.dc:creator: Faseeh Mangi, Kamran Haider

media:content.media:description: Pakistan Air Force J-10C fighter jets perform at a rehearsal ahead of Pakistan's national day parade in Islamabad on March 21, 2024.

item.title: Musk’s Banker Michael Grimes Sells SpaceX, Anduril for Trump Job
item.description: Michael Grimes, the veteran technology investment banker who helped Elon Musk buy Twitter in 2022, reported assets worth as much as $98 million in a financial disclosure as part of his new role at the Commerce Department.
item.dc:creator: Bill Allison, Sophie Alexander

media:content.media:description: Michael Grimes

item.title: DraftKings Anticipates ‘Taking Action’ After Illinois Tax Hike
item.description: Sports-betting operator DraftKings Inc. said it’s weighing its next moves after a recent tax increase in Illinois.
item.dc:creator: Chris Palmeri

media:content.media:description: The logo for DraftKings is displayed on a laptop computer in an arranged photograph taken in Little Falls, New Jersey, U.S., on Wednesday, Oct. 7, 2020. The pricing of a DraftKings Inc. share sale combined with a fresh wave of Covid-19 infections across the National Football League sent shares of the online gaming company tumbling this week. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

item.title: NATO Seeks to Include Ukraine Funds in New Spending Target
item.description: NATO allies will consider allowing contributions to Ukraine’s defense to be included in the new spending target alliance members are expected to adopt at a leaders’ summit later this month.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini, Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: A Ukrainian tank crew of the 33rd Separate Mechanized Brigade fire a round from a Leopard 2A4 tank during a field training exercise at an undisclosed location in Ukraine, on April 30, 2025.

item.title: Bomb Attacks Rock Colombia After Presidential Candidate Shot
item.description: At least 19 explosive blasts rocked southwest Colombia, bringing further terror to a nation still reeling from the attempted assassination of a presidential candidate days earlier.
item.dc:creator: Andreina Itriago, Matthew Bristow

media:content.media:description: The aftermath of a bomb explosion in Cali, Colombia, on June 10.

item.title: Trump’s FAA Nominee Says Air Traffic Needs ‘Significant’ Investment
item.description: President Donald Trump’s pick to lead the Federal Aviation Administration plans to tell lawmakers that modernizing the US air traffic control system needs to be a top funding priority, according to prepared written remarks seen by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Versprille

media:content.media:description: Workers in an air traffic control tower in Miami in 2017. Photographer: Joe Raedle/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Pick Ben Black Seeks More Risk, Private Investors for Development Agency Deals
item.description: President Donald Trump’s surprise pick to lead an obscure federal agency that invests in development finance said he plans to take on more risk and attract private investors to its deals.
item.dc:creator: Loukia Gyftopoulou, Joe Deaux

media:content.media:description: Ben Black, founder of Fortinbras Enterprises, participates in a panel discussion during the Milken Institute Global Conference in Beverly Hills, California, U.S., on Tuesday, May 3, 2022. The event convenes the best minds in the world to tackle its most urgent challenges and to help realize its most exciting opportunities.
